In a turn of events, not unlike the Night of the Long Knives,  "In Burundi, human rights activists have begun documenting a new target of the government’s deadly security forces: members of the feared Imbonerakure youth group who are now killed to ensure their silence" (Ssuuna, 2017). If they, or some of the group, are no longer recognized as an official party militia member, are they civilians?
A violent place that will probably disappear as a country in the near future.
Taking it up to 5%. Burundi instability ticked up slightly.

I see little likelihood of a Burundian or Rwandan mass killing event taking place, primarily due to the strength and vigilance of the Kagame Government in Rwanda. Concomitantly, there is little likelihood of the collapse of the Kagame Govt.

Despite periods of extreme violence in the past tensions at present are restricted to low level events. However a coup (or attempted coup) could lead to a high possibility of wide spread killings as happened in the previous genocides.

Keeping at 3%. You know things are bad in DRC when people leave there for Burundi (a few thousand recently). Burundi might explode given whole Hutu/Tutsi thing and tough neighbourhood. For now 3% though...
Government doesn't want the international attention that a death toll of 1,000 plus brings. More controlled death actions that cause fear from the populace has proven more impactful.
Lots of people are going to die - but unlikely to meet question criteria. Age expectancy 50. Annual income under $1000 and 90% of country poor. Ripe for “something”but likely not in 2018.

While it is highly unlikely that a coordinated group would carry out  deliberate attacks on civilizes to an extent that causality reached 1000 it is still possible due to the mass poverty and large income gap between the ruling class and the majority of poor farmers (90% according to the CIA) https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/by.html, this has been a catalyst for unrest in the past as in 2015 and  1993 but the economy and health situation seems to be getting better since the 2015 conflict so it seems unlikely. more common for conflict to spill over from the boarder of a Neighboring country on accident.
Hundreds die each year (but not a thousand yet) and as pointed out, a dangerous neighbourhood.

There is still a lot of unrest in this region especially with rebel groups conscripting young children into their groups.   I foresee them actually wiping out entire villages in their zeal for change.

Although there still is some risk left that earlier lines of conflict will reheat and result in a new level of violence, Burundi alread has begun to stabilize itself. And since in the last decades violence emerged in the context of elections, the last elections were in 2015 and the normal legislative period lasts 5 years I predict the earliest possible rehappening of greater violence in 2020.
BURUNDI SECURITY FORCES WEAKEN WHILE REBEL FORCES GAIN IN STRENGTH AND POWER.

Lack of conflict resolution milestones and ongoing ethic inequalities fueling negative emotions among groups. This is due to ineffective communication caused by incomplete bilateral perception deficits. However, potential for mediation is present.
